reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-argument in §3.3: that bounded, separate-aggregation views are fussy because even a 1/10^22 fraction of bads (a star-system’s worth) pushes value below the “mostly-great” threshold. That point supports the broader conclusion (“most plausible views are fussy”), but it’s only one branch in a multi-branch case (they also argue linear/unbounded views are fussy, and bounded-universe views are practically linear), so centrality is moderate rather than high. Strength is moderate: it plausibly identifies a load-bearing assumption—treating ‘bads’ as extensive and (effectively) linear in scale even while allowing bounded/concave treatment for goods—and offers a coherent alternative class of bounded views where bads saturate or fail to add up proportionally, which would undercut the specific 10^22-style quantitative fussiness claim. However, the author’s framework in that section explicitly models aggregation by summing bads then applying a bounded transform; the critique’s counterexample shifts to a different kind of non-extensive/thresholded bad measure, so it partly changes the target rather than refuting the argument on its own terms. Correctness is fairly high: it’s right that the argument depends on extensivity/linearity of bad accumulation across scale and that this is a substantive modeling choice; it’s less solid in implying the author “simultaneously” assumes linear bad aggregation while exploring non-linear good aggregation, since the essay’s separate-aggregation model can be non-linear via the bounded transform even if it’s extensive in its pre-transform measure. Clarity is high and dead weight is low. It focuses on essentially one issue. Overall it’s a decent, pointed objection to one pillar, but it doesn’t seriously threaten the essay’s overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion without further work showing that saturating/non-extensive bads are both plausible and common enough to flip the overall fussy-versus-easygoing balance.
title: Bounded disvalue may saturate rather than scale linearly with civilization size
